member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.JsConfig.sThrowOnDeserializationError
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if the framework should throw serialization exceptions or continue regardless of deserialization errors. If the framework will throw; otherwise, it will parse as many fields as possible. The default is .

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.JsConfig.sAlwaysUseUtc
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if the framework should always convert to UTC format instead of local time.

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.JsConfig.sSkipDateTimeConversion
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if the framework should skip automatic conversions. Dates will be handled literally, any included timezone encoding will be lost and the date will be treaded as DateTimeKind.Local Utc formatted input will result in DateTimeKind.Utc output. Any input without TZ data will be set DateTimeKind.Unspecified This will take precedence over other flags like AlwaysUseUtc JsConfig.DateHandler = DateHandler.ISO8601 should be used when set true for consistent de/serialization.

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.JsConfig.sAssumeUtc
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if the framework should always assume is in UTC format if Kind is Unspecified.

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.JsConfig.sAppendUtcOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets whether we should append the Utc offset when we serialize Utc dates. Defaults to no. Only supported for when the JsConfig.DateHandler == JsonDateHandler.TimestampOffset

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.Json.JsonUtils.EscapedBackslash
member.summary: Micro-optimization keep pre-built char arrays saving a .ToCharArray() + function call (see .net implementation of .Write(string))

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Json.JsonUtils.HasAnyEscapeChars(System.String)
member.summary: Searches the string for one or more non-printable characters.
member.returns: True if there are any characters that require escaping. False if the value can be written verbatim.
member.remarks: Micro optimizations: since quote and backslash are the only printable characters requiring escaping, removed previous optimization (using flags instead of value.IndexOfAny(EscapeChars)) in favor of two equality operations saving both memory and CPU time. Also slightly reduced code size by re-arranging conditions. TODO: Possible Linq-only solution requires profiling: return value.Any(c => !c.IsPrintable() || c == QuoteChar || c == EscapeChar);

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.Marc.Link`2
member.summary:
Pretty Thread-Safe cache class from: http://code.google.com/p/dapper-dot-net/source/browse/Dapper/SqlMapper.cs
This is a micro-cache; suitable when the number of terms is controllable (a few hundred, for example), and strictly append-only; you cannot change existing values. All key matches are on **REFERENCE** equality. The type is fully thread-safe.

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.Pools.ObjectPool`1
member.summary:
Generic implementation of object pooling pattern with predefined pool size limit. The main purpose is that limited number of frequently used objects can be kept in the pool for further recycling.
Notes: 1) it is not the goal to keep all returned objects. Pool is not meant for storage. If there is no space in the pool, extra returned objects will be dropped.
2) it is implied that if object was obtained from a pool, the caller will return it back in a relatively short time. Keeping checked out objects for long durations is ok, but reduces usefulness of pooling. Just new up your own.
Not returning objects to the pool in not detrimental to the pool's work, but is a bad practice. Rationale: If there is no intent for reusing the object, do not use pool - just use "new".

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.Pools.ObjectPool`1.Factory
member.remarks: Not using System.Func{T} because this file is linked into the (debugger) Formatter, which does not have that type (since it compiles against .NET 2.0).

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Pools.ObjectPool`1.Allocate
member.summary: Produces an instance.
member.remarks: Search strategy is a simple linear probing which is chosen for it cache-friendliness. Note that Free will try to store recycled objects close to the start thus statistically reducing how far we will typically search.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Pools.ObjectPool`1.Free(`0)
member.summary: Returns objects to the pool.
member.remarks: Search strategy is a simple linear probing which is chosen for it cache-friendliness. Note that Free will try to store recycled objects close to the start thus statistically reducing how far we will typically search in Allocate.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Pools.ObjectPool`1.ForgetTrackedObject(`0,`0)
member.summary:
Removes an object from leak tracking.
This is called when an object is returned to the pool. It may also be explicitly called if an object allocated from the pool is intentionally not being returned to the pool. This can be of use with pooled arrays if the consumer wants to return a larger array to the pool than was originally allocated.

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.Pools.PooledObject`1
member.summary: this is RAII object to automatically release pooled object when its owning pool

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.Pools.SharedPools
member.summary:
Shared object pool for roslyn
Use this shared pool if only concern is reducing object allocations. if perf of an object pool itself is also a concern, use ObjectPool directly.
For example, if you want to create a million of small objects within a second, use the ObjectPool directly. it should have much less overhead than using this.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Pools.SharedPools.BigDefault``1
member.summary: pool that uses default constructor with 100 elements pooled

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Pools.SharedPools.Default``1
member.summary: pool that uses default constructor with 20 elements pooled

member.summary: pool that uses string as key with StringComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase as key comparer

member.summary: pool that uses string as element with StringComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase as element comparer

member.summary: pool that uses string as element with StringComparer.Ordinal as element comparer

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager
member.summary: Manages pools of RecyclableMemoryStream objects.
member.remarks:
There are two pools managed in here. The small pool contains same-sized buffers that are handed to streams as they write more data.
For scenarios that need to call GetBuffer(), the large pool contains buffers of various sizes, all multiples of LargeBufferMultiple (1 MB by default). They are split by size to avoid overly-wasteful buffer usage. There should be far fewer 8 MB buffers than 1 MB buffers, for example.

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.EventHandler
member.summary: Generic delegate for handling events without any arguments.

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.LargeBufferDiscardedEventHandler
member.summary: Delegate for handling large buffer discard reports.

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.StreamLengthReportHandler
member.summary: Delegate for handling reports of stream size when streams are allocated

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.UsageReportEventHandler
member.summary: Delegate for handling periodic reporting of memory use statistics.
member.param: Bytes currently in use in the small pool.
Bytes currently free in the small pool.
Bytes currently in use in the large pool.
Bytes currently free in the large pool.

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.largePools
member.summary: pools[0] = 1x largeBufferMultiple buffers pools[1] = 2x largeBufferMultiple buffers etc., up to maximumBufferSize

member.summary: Initializes the memory manager with the given block requiredSize.
member.param: Size of each block that is pooled. Must be > 0.
Each large buffer will be a multiple of this value.
Buffers larger than this are not pooled
member.exception: blockSize is not a positive number, or largeBufferMultiple is not a positive number, or maximumBufferSize is less than blockSize.
maximumBufferSize is not a multiple of largeBufferMultiple

member.summary: How many bytes of small free blocks to allow before we start dropping those returned to us.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.MaximumFreeLargePoolBytes
member.summary: How many bytes of large free buffers to allow before we start dropping those returned to us.

member.summary: Maximum stream capacity in bytes. Attempts to set a larger capacity will result in an exception.
member.remarks: A value of 0 indicates no limit.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GenerateCallStacks
member.summary: Whether to save callstacks for stream allocations. This can help in debugging. It should NEVER be turned on generally in production.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.AggressiveBufferReturn
member.summary: Whether dirty buffers can be immediately returned to the buffer pool. E.g. when GetBuffer() is called on a stream and creates a single large buffer, if this setting is enabled, the other blocks will be returned to the buffer pool immediately. Note when enabling this setting that the user is responsible for ensuring that any buffer previously retrieved from a stream which is subsequently modified is not used after modification (as it may no longer be valid).

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetBlock
member.summary: Removes and returns a single block from the pool.

member.summary: Returns a buffer of arbitrary size from the large buffer pool. This buffer will be at least the requiredSize and always be a multiple of largeBufferMultiple.
member.param: The minimum length of the buffer
The tag of the stream returning this buffer, for logging if necessary.
member.returns: A buffer of at least the required size.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetStream(System.String,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieve a new MemoryStream object with the given tag and at least the given capacity, possibly using a single continugous underlying buffer.
member.remarks: Retrieving a MemoryStream which provides a single contiguous buffer can be useful in situations where the initial size is known and it is desirable to avoid copying data between the smaller underlying buffers to a single large one. This is most helpful when you know that you will always call GetBuffer on the underlying stream.
member.param: A tag which can be used to track the source of the stream.
The minimum desired capacity for the stream.
Whether to attempt to use a single contiguous buffer.

member.summary: Retrieve a new MemoryStream object with the given tag and with contents copied from the provided buffer. The provided buffer is not wrapped or used after construction.
member.remarks: The new stream's position is set to the beginning of the stream when returned.
member.param: A tag which can be used to track the source of the stream.
The byte buffer to copy data from.
The offset from the start of the buffer to copy from.
The number of bytes to copy from the buffer.

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream
member.summary: MemoryStream implementation that deals with pooling and managing memory streams which use potentially large buffers.
member.remarks:
This class works in tandem with the RecylableMemoryStreamManager to supply MemoryStream objects to callers, while avoiding these specific problems: 1. LOH allocations - since all large buffers are pooled, they will never incur a Gen2 GC 2. Memory waste - A standard memory stream doubles its size when it runs out of room. This leads to continual memory growth as each stream approaches the maximum allowed size. 3. Memory copying - Each time a MemoryStream grows, all the bytes are copied into new buffers. This implementation only copies the bytes when GetBuffer is called. 4. Memory fragmentation - By using homogeneous buffer sizes, it ensures that blocks of memory can be easily reused.
The stream is implemented on top of a series of uniformly-sized blocks. As the stream's length grows, additional blocks are retrieved from the memory manager. It is these blocks that are pooled, not the stream object itself.
The biggest wrinkle in this implementation is when GetBuffer() is called. This requires a single contiguous buffer. If only a single block is in use, then that block is returned. If multiple blocks are in use, we retrieve a larger buffer from the memory manager. These large buffers are also pooled, split by size--they are multiples of a chunk size (1 MB by default).
Once a large buffer is assigned to the stream the blocks are NEVER again used for this stream. All operations take place on the large buffer. The large buffer can be replaced by a larger buffer from the pool as needed. All blocks and large buffers are maintained in the stream until the stream is disposed (unless AggressiveBufferReturn is enabled in the stream manager).

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.blocks
member.summary: All of these blocks must be the same size

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.largeBuffer
member.summary: This is only set by GetBuffer() if the necessary buffer is larger than a single block size, or on construction if the caller immediately requests a single large buffer.
member.remarks: If this field is non-null, it contains the concatenation of the bytes found in the individual blocks. Once it is created, this (or a larger) largeBuffer will be used for the life of the stream.

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.dirtyBuffers
member.summary: This list is used to store buffers once they're replaced by something larger. This is for the cases where you have users of this class that may hold onto the buffers longer than they should and you want to prevent race conditions which could corrupt the data.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.Id
member.summary: Unique identifier for this stream across it's entire lifetime

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.Tag
member.summary: A temporary identifier for the current usage of this stream.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.MemoryManager
member.summary: Gets the memory manager being used by this stream.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.AllocationStack
member.summary: Callstack of the constructor. It is only set if MemoryManager.GenerateCallStacks is true, which should only be in debugging situations.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.DisposeStack
member.summary: Callstack of the Dispose call. It is only set if MemoryManager.GenerateCallStacks is true, which should only be in debugging situations.

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.byteBuffer
member.summary: This buffer exists so that WriteByte can forward all of its calls to Write without creating a new byte[] buffer on every call.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.#ctor(ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager)
member.summary: Allocate a new RecyclableMemoryStream object.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.#ctor(ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager,System.String)
member.summary: Allocate a new RecyclableMemoryStream object
member.param: A string identifying this stream for logging and debugging purposes

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.#ctor(ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Allocate a new RecyclableMemoryStream object
member.param: A string identifying this stream for logging and debugging purposes
The initial requested size to prevent future allocations

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.#ctor(ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager,System.String,System.Int32,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Allocate a new RecyclableMemoryStream object
member.param: A string identifying this stream for logging and debugging purposes
The initial requested size to prevent future allocations
An initial buffer to use. This buffer will be owned by the stream and returned to the memory manager upon Dispose.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the memory used by this stream back to the pool.
member.param: Whether we're disposing (true), or being called by the finalizer (false)
member.remarks: This method is not thread safe and it may not be called more than once.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.Close
member.summary: Equivalent to Dispose

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.Capacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the capacity
member.remarks: Capacity is always in multiples of the memory manager's block size, unless the large buffer is in use. Capacity never decreases during a stream's lifetime. Explicitly setting the capacity to a lower value than the current value will have no effect. This is because the buffers are all pooled by chunks and there's little reason to allow stream truncation.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.Length
member.summary: Gets the number of bytes written to this stream.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.Position
member.summary: Gets the current position in the stream

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.CanRead
member.summary: Whether the stream can currently read

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.CanSeek
member.summary: Whether the stream can currently seek

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.CanTimeout
member.summary: Always false

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.CanWrite
member.summary: Whether the stream can currently write

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.GetBuffer
member.summary: Returns a single buffer containing the contents of the stream. The buffer may be longer than the stream length.
member.remarks: IMPORTANT: Doing a Write() after calling GetBuffer() invalidates the buffer. The old buffer is held onto until Dispose is called, but the next time GetBuffer() is called, a new buffer from the pool will be required.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.ToArray
member.summary: Returns a new array with a copy of the buffer's contents. You should almost certainly be using GetBuffer combined with the Length to access the bytes in this stream. Calling ToArray will destroy the benefits of pooled buffers, but it is included for the sake of completeness.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads from the current position into the provided buffer
member.param: Offset into buffer at which to start placing the read bytes.
member.exception: offset or count is less than 0
offset subtracted from the buffer length is less than count

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes the buffer to the stream
member.exception: buffer.Length - offset is not less than count

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.ToString
member.summary: Returns a useful string for debugging. This should not normally be called in actual production code.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.WriteByte(System.Byte)
member.summary: Writes a single byte to the current position in the stream.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.ReadByte
member.summary: Reads a single byte from the current position in the stream.
member.returns: The byte at the current position, or -1 if the position is at the end of the stream.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.SetLength(System.Int64)
member.summary: Sets the length of the stream
member.exception: value is negative or larger than MaxStreamLength

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.Seek(System.Int64,System.IO.SeekOrigin)
member.summary: Sets the position to the offset from the seek location

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.WriteTo(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Synchronously writes this stream's bytes to the parameter stream.
member.remarks: Important: This does a synchronous write, which may not be desired in some situations

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.RecyclableMemoryStream.ReleaseLargeBuffer
member.summary: Release the large buffer (either stores it for eventual release or returns it immediately).

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Text.Support.DoubleConverter
member.summary:
A class to allow the conversion of doubles to string representations of their exact decimal values. The implementation aims for readability over efficiency.
Courtesy of @JonSkeet http://www.yoda.arachsys.com/csharp/DoubleConverter.cs

member.name: F:ServiceStack.Text.Support.DoubleConverter.ArbitraryDecimal.decimalPoint
member.summary: How many digits are *after* the decimal point

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Support.DoubleConverter.ArbitraryDecimal.#ctor(System.Int64)
member.summary: Constructs an arbitrary decimal expansion from the given long. The long must not be negative.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Support.DoubleConverter.ArbitraryDecimal.MultiplyBy(System.Int32)
member.summary: Multiplies the current expansion by the given amount, which should only be 2 or 5.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Support.DoubleConverter.ArbitraryDecimal.Shift(System.Int32)
member.summary: Shifts the decimal point; a negative value makes the decimal expansion bigger (as fewer digits come after the decimal place) and a positive value makes the decimal expansion smaller.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Support.DoubleConverter.ArbitraryDecimal.Normalize
member.summary: Removes leading/trailing zeroes from the expansion.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Text.Support.DoubleConverter.ArbitraryDecimal.ToString
member.summary: Converts the value to a proper decimal string representation.

member.name: F:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.DefaultBufferSize
member.summary: @jonskeet: Collection of utility methods which operate on streams. r285, February 26th 2009: http://www.yoda.arachsys.com/csharp/miscutil/

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.ReadFully(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Reads the given stream up to the end, returning the data as a byte array.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.ReadFully(System.IO.Stream,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads the given stream up to the end, returning the data as a byte array, using the given buffer size.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.ReadFully(System.IO.Stream,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Reads the given stream up to the end, returning the data as a byte array, using the given buffer for transferring data. Note that the current contents of the buffer is ignored, so the buffer needn't be cleared beforehand.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.CopyTo(System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Copies all the data from one stream into another.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.CopyTo(System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream,System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies all the data from one stream into another, using a buffer of the given size.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.CopyTo(System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Copies all the data from one stream into another, using the given buffer for transferring data. Note that the current contents of the buffer is ignored, so the buffer needn't be cleared beforehand.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.ReadExactly(System.IO.Stream,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads exactly the given number of bytes from the specified stream. If the end of the stream is reached before the specified amount of data is read, an exception is thrown.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.ReadExactly(System.IO.Stream,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Reads into a buffer, filling it completely.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.ReadExactly(System.IO.Stream,System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads exactly the given number of bytes from the specified stream, into the given buffer, starting at position 0 of the array.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.ReadExactly(System.IO.Stream,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads exactly the given number of bytes from the specified stream, into the given buffer, starting at position 0 of the array.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.StreamExtensions.ReadExactlyFast(System.IO.Stream,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Same as ReadExactly, but without the argument checks.
